John G. raped and murdered my wife.

This VES (Visual and Environmental Studies Department of Harvard University) screening of Memento is free and open to the general public. As a public service announcement, please note that The Matrix is also being shown on this Wednesday, April 14th, 2010, also at the Harvard Film Archive. Feel free to place it on the calendar as an event!

About Memento (According to Wikipedia):
http://en.wikipedia.o...)

"Memento is a 2000 psychological thriller film written and directed by Christopher Nolan, adapted from his younger brother Jonathan's short story 'Memento Mori'. It stars Guy Pearce [L.A. Confidential] as Leonard Shelby, a man with anterograde amnesia which renders his brain unable to store new memories. During the opening credits, (which portrays the end of the story) we are shown that Leonard has just killed [...]

... Let's just say that over the course of the film, you see Leonard kill a man, and part of the fun is watching the movie unfold as you try to decipher Leonard's reasons for committing that cold-blooded act as the movie slowly unfolds.

"This film is often used to show the distinction between plot and story. The film's events unfold in two separate, alternating narrativesâ€”one in color, and the other in black and white. The black and white sections are told in chronological order, showing Leonard conversing with an anonymous phone caller in a motel room. Leonard's investigation is depicted in color sequences that are in reverse chronological order. As each sequence begins, the spectator is unaware of the preceding events, just like Leonard, thereby giving the viewer a sense of his confusion. By the film's end when the two narratives converge we understand the investigation and the events that lead up to the death of [the victim].

"Memento premiered on September 5, 2000 at the Venice Film Festival to critical acclaim and received a similar response when it was released in European theaters starting in October 2000. Critics especially praised its unique, nonlinear narrative structure and themes of memory, perception, grief, self-deception, and revenge. The film was successful at the box office and received numerous accolades, including Academy Award nominations for Original Screenplay and Editing".

... Come, let us get confused together, then try to sort it all out over beer.

Where to Meet:

Care to grab a bite to eat beforehand? T.J. Maher will be at food court at the lower level of The Garage near the Subway sandwich shop starting at 5:45 pm. We can walk over to the Harvard Film Archive at 6:30 pm to grab seats. T.J. Maher is 5 foot 7, with short brown hair, blue eyes, a "Hello My Name is T.J." nametag, and a red MEETUP sign attached to his black messenger bag.

About Christopher Nolan:
http://en.wikipedia.o...

"Christopher Jonathan James Nolan (born 30 July 1970) is an English filmmaker, writer and producer. The son of an English father and an American mother, Nolan is a dual citizen of the United Kingdom and the United States. He is married to Emma Thomas, his longtime producer. They have three children and reside in Los Angeles.

"He often collaborates with his brother, screenwriter Jonathan Nolan, and recently with actor Christian Bale (Batman Begins, The Dark Knight, and The Prestige) and Michael Caine in the same films. Nolan is best known for directing the psychological thriller Memento and for reviving the Batman film franchise, for which he has received considerable acclaim. He is also the founder of the production company Syncopy Films".

... Nolan also directed The Prestige and Insomnia.

Directions:
"The Harvard Film Archive is located in the lower level of the Carpenter Center for the Visual Arts at 24 Quincy Street, in Cambridge, Massachusetts. We are east of the Harvard Square Red Line T Stop, in between the Harvard Faculty Club and the Fogg Art Museum, one block north of Massachusetts Avenue between Broadway and Harvard Streets in the Harvard University campus".

Parking:
"Although parking in Cambridge is difficult (most of the surrounding streets have restricted parking for Cambridge residents only), metered parking on Broadway and Harvard Streets, as well as the rest of Harvard Square, is free after 6 pm. Film-goers are encouraged to use public transportation, particularly the MBTA Red Line".
